subject: Re: overriding a method executed in the constructor: dont't work.
msgSnippet: ... Well, it s not recommended, but I wouldn t call it no man s land . It s pretty clearly specified. The problem I ve seen in the past with calling
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Jeff Nielsen" <jeff.nielsen@d...> wrote:
> By calling an (overloaded) class method from within the constructor
> you're getting into no man's land with the intricacies of the Java
> runtime.

Well, it's not recommended, but I wouldn't call it "no man's land".
It's pretty clearly specified. The problem I've seen in the past with
calling overridden methods in a constructor is that the variables in
the subclass are initialised *after* the superclass constructor
returns. That means any changes you make to the subclass variables in
the overridden method are lost (at least if there is explicit
initialisation). It also means that the method will be called without
the initialisation having taken place, so it's effectively running in
a partially constructed context.

So yes, it's generally not a good idea, but very occasionally it can
be the simplest way of working, and it should certainly work in the
OP's case - and does for me... I'd be interested to try to work out
exactly why it doesn't on the OP's box.

Jon
